title: Introduction to the Panel
segmentation: Look forward to better listen to what the panel panelists have to say.
I welcome you to this session.
This is the Security 2007 panel.
The title, as you see on the screen is data mining at the crossroads successes, failures and what we can learn from them.
I'm concerned about some practice Arity, and the panelists are pal Birkin from Yahoo.
Christos pollutes us from CMU Jeyhan from UIUC, aim harsh from.
NSF and Rutgers University and John Elder from Elder Research.
So why are we here today and what are we discussing?
So I like to define the field wherein the theme of the field we're in is something that's concerned with extracting actionable and interpretable knowledge in as efficient a manner as possible.

Now there are a host of different algorithms that are efficient, but they often produce results that are not quite interpretable or not quite useful, and so success and failure in some senses have to be defined.
In terms of how they accommodate all three criteria, so the panel objectives are to reflect on how successful we have been, what have been the missteps and failures?
And I ask ourselves what we can learn from them so.
Her stories essentially we're looking with asking the panelists to identify.

And while the panelists are identifying, I encourage the audience members to think about whether we're missing something, whether whether there should be something else that's being discussed in this context, reflect about successes in the context of progress in Cork, ated fields, breakthrough algorithms that have changed certain aspects of how we live, impact on real applications and deployment, educational and organizational success is like this particular conference, for example.
And of course, a host of other.
Examples, failures and mistakes are often a little harder to characterize.
There are many different definitions possible for failures, so one example could be a failure to adapt or to progress in line with an expectation.
So there was a very interesting paper discussing paper in statistical science last year written by David Hand and others where they discussed the illusion of progress in classification.
So that could be a topic.
That's Meritas web.
Discussing failure to adapt to application and end user requirements.
Examples include how far have we come along in terms of producing interpretable results.

How do we know what's interesting, classic mistakes in the field, and other issues that several talks already have discussed in terms of reproducibility of results and the need for large scale benchmarks?
And finally, the panelists will be asked to conclude in terms of their future outlook.
What can we learn from our successes and failures, and where does emerging technology play a role in all of this?
So without fail?
Radu I'd like to invite Pavel Birkin to give his comments on the topic.
